thread.name: Infrahub SDK get on nested nodes

messages.content: Thanks for your help Urs, much appreciated!
I am glad it works now. I assume you can remove the first fetch when you use `include` for the get. Not sure if there is even a way to fetch 2 levels.

ah it converts to IPv4Interface object,
application.cluster.peer.primary_address.peer.address.value.ip is what i was looking for
got confused by gql syntax
Looks good to me. `value` contains the IPv4Interface object (python builtin object for IPv4 Address with a network mask)

initialized = True 
inspect(application.cluster.peer.primary_address.peer.address)
â•­â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ <class 'infrahub_sdk.node.attribute.Attribute'> â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â•®
â”‚ Represents an attribute of a Node, including its schema, value, and properties. â”‚
â”‚                                                                                 â”‚
â”‚ â•­â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â•® â”‚
â”‚ â”‚ <infrahub_sdk.node.attribute.Attribute object at 0x10c341960>               â”‚ â”‚
â”‚ â•°â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â•¯ â”‚
â”‚                                                                                 â”‚
â”‚                     id = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚             is_default = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚        is_from_profile = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚           is_inherited = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚           is_protected = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚             is_visible = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚                   name = 'address'                                              â”‚
â”‚                  owner = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚                 source = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚             updated_at = None                                                   â”‚
â”‚                  value = IPv4Interface('10.17.90.12/24')                        â”‚
â”‚ value_has_been_mutated = False                                                  â”‚

That's strange. Can you check if the primary_address is "initialized"?
```
application = await infc.get(kind=webhook_data.data.target_kind, id=webhook_data.data.target_id)
await application.cluster.fetch()
await application.cluster.peer.primary_address.fetch()

from rich import inspect
inspect(application.cluster.peer.primary_address)
inspect(application.cluster.peer.primary_address.peer)
```

bingo, now it works!
but the property ip is still not fetched :/
can you try the last snippet with the `peer` level? I edited it

This produces
AttributeError: 'RelatedNode' object has no attribute 'primary_address'
again

inspecting shows just the usual
â”‚    display_label = 'lab-f5-10'                                          â”‚
â”‚             hfid = ['lab-f5-10']                                        â”‚
â”‚         hfid_str = 'InfraF5Cluster__lab-f5-10'                          â”‚
â”‚               id = '1849e5b2-e004-bd09-ef5c-c515cd2fd77a'               â”‚
â”‚      initialized = True                                                 â”‚
â”‚     is_protected = None                                                 â”‚
â”‚ is_resource_pool = False                                                â”‚
â”‚       is_visible = None                                                 â”‚
â”‚             name = 'cluster'                                            â”‚
â”‚            owner = None                                                 â”‚
â”‚             peer = lab-f5-10                                            â”‚
â”‚           schema = RelationshipSchemaAPI
...
â”‚           source = None                                                 â”‚
â”‚         typename = 'InfraF5Cluster'                                     â”‚
â”‚       updated_at = None                                                 â”‚

usualy just use dir() ğŸ˜„ the inspect is handy

```
application = await infc.get(kind=webhook_data.data.target_kind, id=webhook_data.data.target_id)
await application.cluster.fetch()
await application.cluster.peer.primary_address.fetch()
print(application.cluster.peer.primary_address.peer.address.value)
```

hmmm. The RelatedNode indicate I missed one level. 
I am just guessing but if I remember correctly it could be like this for cardinality one relations
i normally use the pdb for debugging on the fly

otherwise run the following
```
application = await infc.get(kind=webhook_data.data.target_kind, id=webhook_data.data.target_id)
await application.cluster.fetch()
from rich import inspect
inspect(application.cluster)
await application.cluster.primary_address.fetch()
print(application.cluster.primary_address.primary_address.address.value)
```
Do you have a simple way to debug your code?

this produces
AttributeError: 'RelatedNode' object has no attribute 'primary_address'

I think the it should not be necessary to access the fetched object from the store. Something like this does not work?
```
application = await infc.get(kind=webhook_data.data.target_kind, id=webhook_data.data.target_id)
await application.cluster.fetch()
await application.cluster.primary_address.fetch()
print(application.cluster.primary_address.primary_address.address.value)
```

prefetch_relationships only works one level deep, but fetch with object store works, thanks!
```
    application = await infc.get(kind=webhook_data.data.target_kind, id=webhook_data.data.target_id)
    await application.cluster.fetch()
    cluster = infc.store.get(key=application.cluster.id)
    await cluster.primary_address.fetch()
    primary_address = infc.store.get(key=cluster.primary_address.id)
    print(primary_address.address.value)
```
one detail, only value property is available on address attribute
property=True parameter in preceding get does not work for me here.
```
    primary_address = infc.store.get(key=cluster.primary_address.id, property=True)
    print(primary_address.address.ip)
```
produces
```
TypeError: NodeStore.get() got an unexpected keyword argument 'property'
```
https://docs.infrahub.app/python-sdk/guides/store

embeds.title: Using the client store | Infrahub Documentation
embeds.description: The client in the SDK contains a store that is used to store objects in a local cache.

messages.content:
I am definitely no export but maybe I can help anyway ğŸ˜‰ . Do you get any error message when using include or fetch?
There is also the `prefetch_relationships=True` option you can set but I assume it is only one level
